Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, \u00a7 4 (venue.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, § 4 (venue for actions against individuals).
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, \u00a7 4 (venue.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex Superior Court, Newton Division, because the tort occurred in Newton Commonwealth Park, Newton, Massachusetts.

Town of Lexington v. Leno, 436 Mass. 456.raw_text: Town of Lexington v. Leno, 436 Mass. 456, 466 (2002) (recognition of duty principles)
Town of Lexington v. Leno, 436 Mass. 456.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm to others.
Town of Lexington v. Leno, 436 Mass. 456.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly grounds criminal duty principles in Massachusetts civil duty doctrine and adopts Restatement (Second) of Torts § 321’s rule that one who creates an unreasonable risk has a duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent that risk from taking effect. The court further states that Massachusetts law, “both civil and criminal, imposes on people a duty to act reasonably,” which directly aligns with the claimed proposition about a duty of reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm to others.
Town of Lexington v. Leno, 436 Mass. 456.relevant_excerpt: “Our law, both civil and criminal, imposes on people a duty to act reasonably. See Onofrio v. Department of Mental Health, 408 Mass. 605, 610 (1990)… The Restatement (Second) of Torts § 321 (1) (1965) reads: ‘If the actor does an act, and subsequently realizes or should realize that it has created an unreasonable risk of causing physical harm to another, he is under a duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent the risk from taking effect.’ … [W]here one’s actions create a life-threatening risk to another, there is a duty to take reasonable steps to alleviate the risk.”

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 140 (dog-control sta.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 140 (dog-control statutes and regulation of animals in public places).
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 140 (dog-control sta.proposition: Defendant owed a duty to persons lawfully using the park and its paths, including Plaintiff, to exercise reasonable care in controlling the Dog and to comply with posted leash requirements, thereby preventing foreseeable injury to foreseeable users of the park.

Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) (proximate cause principles)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: Defendant’s breach was a proximate and actual cause of Plaintiff’s fall, physical injuries (including a fractured wrist), medical expenses, lost income, and other damages.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that the defendant’s breach was a proximate and actual cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. In Palsgraf, the majority explicitly holds that, as to Mrs. Palsgraf, the railroad’s conduct was not negligent at all and thus there was no actionable wrong or proximate cause linking the guards’ acts to her injuries. The opinion is frequently cited for limiting liability based on duty and foreseeability, not for finding proximate cause for a plaintiff’s physical injuries and related damages.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: “The conduct of the defendant’s guard, if a wrong in its relation to the holder of the package, was not a wrong in its relation to the plaintiff, standing far away. Relatively to her it was not negligence at all… The law of causation, remote or proximate, is thus foreign to the case before us. The question of liability is always anterior to the question of the measure of the consequences that go with liability… If there is no tort to be redressed, there is no occasion to consider what damage might be recovered if there were a finding of a tort.”

Wiseman v. Jinsai, 472 Mass. 1002 (2015).raw_text: Wiseman v. Jinsai, 472 Mass. 1002 (2015) (discussing duty and foreseeability)
Wiseman v. Jinsai, 472 Mass. 1002 (2015).proposition: The elements of negligence—duty, breach, causation, and damages—are well-established in Massachusetts law and the common law.
Wiseman v. Jinsai, 472 Mass. 1002 (2015).support_reasoning: This opinion concerns the availability of relief under G. L. c. 211, § 3, and habeas corpus, and the relationship of those extraordinary remedies to the normal appellate process. It does not discuss negligence, duty, breach, causation, damages, or any tort principles. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition about the well-established elements of negligence in Massachusetts law.
Wiseman v. Jinsai, 472 Mass. 1002 (2015).relevant_excerpt: The single justice neither erred nor abused his discretion in denying relief. To the extent the petition can be viewed as seeking relief under G. L. c. 211, § 3, the errors claimed in the petition either were or could have been raised in the petitioner’s direct appeal, or in a motion for postconviction relief under Mass. R. Crim. P. 30... Where adequate remedies alternative to G. L. c. 211, § 3, are available, relief properly is denied.

Schwartz v. Shepard, 343 Mass. 118 (1961.raw_text: Schwartz v. Shepard, 343 Mass. 118 (1961) (liability of keeper of animal for injuries caused by the animal’s dangerous tendencies)
Schwartz v. Shepard, 343 Mass. 118 (1961.proposition: Massachusetts caselaw recognizes owner liability for negligent handling or control of animals where such negligence causes foreseeable harm to others.
Schwartz v. Shepard, 343 Mass. 118 (1961.support_reasoning: This opinion is a Massachusetts tax case about the deductibility of federal income tax payments and the statutory meaning of “deficiency” under G.L. c. 62 and the Internal Revenue Code. It does not involve animals, owner liability, negligence, or foreseeability of harm, and therefore cannot provide authority for the stated proposition about negligent handling or control of animals. The citation appears to be entirely mismatched to the proposition claimed.
Schwartz v. Shepard, 343 Mass. 118 (1961.relevant_excerpt: We hold, as did the board, that we must look to the Int. Rev. Code of 1954 (Title 26 of the U. S. C. [1958]) to determine the meaning of the term “deficiency.” Section 6211 establishes that (where, as here, no previous deficiency assessment or rebate of the relevant Federal tax has been shown to have been made) the term “means the amount by which the tax imposed by” the provisions of the Internal Revenue Code “exceeds ... the amount shown as the tax by the taxpayer upon his [Federal] return...”

Smith v. Rogers, 350 Mass. 543 (1966) (c.proposition: Massachusetts caselaw recognizes owner liability for negligent handling or control of animals where such negligence causes foreseeable harm to others.
